member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualBasic.Math.crandn.randn(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: 生成标准正态分布随机矩阵
member.param: 矩阵维数
矩阵维数
混合同余种子
member.remarks: 由于矩阵的行和列都可能为奇数，所以先判断总元素 的奇偶性，如果是偶数，先生成偶数随机向量，后把 随机向量赋值给随机矩阵。 如果总元素为奇数，按照VEC rand中类似的方法先 生成随机向量，后把向量复制给随机矩阵。

member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualBasic.Math.FastRandom
member.summary:
A fast random number generator for .NET, from https://www.codeproject.com/Articles/9187/A-fast-equivalent-for-System-Random Colin Green, January 2005
September 4th 2005 Added NextBytesUnsafe() - commented out by default. Fixed bug in Reinitialise() - y,z and w variables were not being reset.
Key points: 1) Based on a simple and fast xor-shift pseudo random number generator (RNG) specified in: Marsaglia, George. (2003). Xorshift RNGs. http://www.jstatsoft.org/v08/i14/xorshift.pdf
This particular implementation of xorshift has a period of 2^128-1. See the above paper to see how this can be easily extened if you need a longer period. At the time of writing I could find no information on the period of System.Random for comparison.
2) Faster than System.Random. Up to 8x faster, depending on which methods are called.
3) Direct replacement for System.Random. This class implements all of the methods that System.Random does plus some additional methods. The like named methods are functionally equivalent.
4) Allows fast re-initialisation with a seed, unlike System.Random which accepts a seed at construction time which then executes a relatively expensive initialisation routine. This provides a vast speed improvement if you need to reset the pseudo-random number sequence many times, e.g. if you want to re-generate the same sequence many times. An alternative might be to cache random numbers in an array, but that approach is limited by memory capacity and the fact that you may also want a large number of different sequences cached. Each sequence can each be represented by a single seed value (int) when using FastRandom.
Notes. A further performance improvement can be obtained by declaring local variables as static, thus avoiding re-allocation of variables on each call. However care should be taken if multiple instances of FastRandom are in use or if being used in a multi-threaded environment.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualBasic.Math.FastRandom.#ctor
member.summary: Initialises a new instance using time dependent seed.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualBasic.Math.FastRandom.#ctor(System.Int32)
member.summary: Initialises a new instance using an int value as seed. This constructor signature is provided to maintain compatibility with System.Random

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualBasic.Math.FastRandom.Reinitialise(System.Int32)
member.summary: Reinitialises using an int value as a seed.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualBasic.Math.FastRandom.Next
member.summary:
Generates a random int over the range 0 to int.MaxValue-1. MaxValue is not generated in order to remain functionally equivalent to System.Random.Next(). This does slightly eat into some of the performance gain over System.Random, but not much. For better performance see:
Call NextInt() for an int over the range 0 to int.MaxValue.
Call NextUInt() and cast the result to an int to generate an int over the full Int32 value range including negative values.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualBasic.Math.FastRandom.Next(System.Int32)
member.summary: Generates a random int over the range 0 to upperBound-1, and not including upperBound.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualBasic.Math.FastRandom.Next(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Generates a random int over the range lowerBound to upperBound-1, and not including upperBound. upperBound must be >= lowerBound. lowerBound may be negative.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualBasic.Math.FastRandom.NextDouble
member.summary: Generates a random double. Values returned are from 0.0 up to but not including 1.0.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualBasic.Math.FastRandom.NextFloat
member.summary: Generates a random double. Values returned are from 0.0 up to but not including 1.0.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualBasic.Math.FastRandom.NextFloats(System.Double[])
member.summary: Fills the provided byte array with random floats.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualBasic.Math.FastRandom.NextBytes(System.Byte[])
member.summary: Fills the provided byte array with random bytes. This method is functionally equivalent to System.Random.NextBytes().

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualBasic.Math.FastRandom.NextUInt
member.summary:
Generates a uint. Values returned are over the full range of a uint, uint.MinValue to uint.MaxValue, inclusive.
This is the fastest method for generating a single random number because the underlying random number generator algorithm generates 32 random bits that can be cast directly to a uint.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualBasic.Math.FastRandom.NextInt
member.summary:
Generates a random int over the range 0 to int.MaxValue, inclusive. This method differs from Next() only in that the range is 0 to int.MaxValue and not 0 to int.MaxValue-1.
The slight difference in range means this method is slightly faster than Next() but is not functionally equivalent to System.Random.Next().

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualBasic.Math.FastRandom.NextBool
member.summary: Generates a single random bit. This method's performance is improved by generating 32 bits in one operation and storing them ready for future calls.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualBasic.Math.IProvideRandomValues.NextFloat
member.summary: Generates a random float. Values returned are from 0.0 up to but not including 1.0.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualBasic.Math.IProvideRandomValues.NextFloats(System.Double[])
member.summary: Fills the elements of a specified array of bytes with random numbers.
member.param: An array of bytes to contain random numbers.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualBasic.Math.IProvideRandomValues.Next(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns a random integer that is within a specified range.
member.param: The inclusive lower bound of the random number returned.
The exclusive upper bound of the random number returned. maxValue must be greater than or equal to minValue.
member.returns: A 32-bit signed integer greater than or equal to minValue and less than maxValue; that is, the range of return values includes minValue but not maxValue. If minValue equals maxValue, minValue is returned.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualBasic.Math.ThreadSafeFastRandom.Next
member.summary: Returns a non-negative random integer.
member.returns: A 32-bit signed integer that is greater than or equal to 0 and less than System.Int32.MaxValue.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualBasic.Math.ThreadSafeFastRandom.Next(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns a non-negative random integer that is less than the specified maximum.
member.param: The exclusive upper bound of the random number to be generated. maxValue must be greater than or equal to 0.
member.returns: A 32-bit signed integer that is greater than or equal to 0, and less than maxValue; that is, the range of return values ordinarily includes 0 but not maxValue. However, if maxValue equals 0, maxValue is returned.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualBasic.Math.ThreadSafeFastRandom.Next(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns a random integer that is within a specified range.
member.param: The inclusive lower bound of the random number returned.
The exclusive upper bound of the random number returned. maxValue must be greater than or equal to minValue.
member.returns: A 32-bit signed integer greater than or equal to minValue and less than maxValue; that is, the range of return values includes minValue but not maxValue. If minValue equals maxValue, minValue is returned.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualBasic.Math.ThreadSafeFastRandom.NextFloat
member.summary: Generates a random float. Values returned are from 0.0 up to but not including 1.0.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualBasic.Math.ThreadSafeFastRandom.NextFloats(System.Double[])
member.summary: Fills the elements of a specified array of bytes with random numbers.
member.param: An array of bytes to contain random numbers.

member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualBasic.Math.MersenneTwisterFast
member.summary:
MersenneTwisterFast:
A simulation quality fast random number generator (MT19937) with the same public methods as java.util.Random.
About the Mersenne Twister. This is a Java version of the C-program for MT19937: Integer version. next(32) generates one pseudorandom unsigned integer (32bit) which is uniformly distributed among 0 to 2^32-1 for each call. next(int bits) >>>'s by (32-bits) to get a value ranging between 0 and 2^bits-1 long inclusive; hope that's correct. setSeed(seed) set initial values to the working area of 624 words. For setSeed(seed), seed is any 32-bit integer except for 0.
Reference. M. Matsumoto and T. Nishimura, "Mersenne Twister: A 623-Dimensionally Equidistributed Uniform Pseudo-Random Number Generator", ACM Transactions on Modeling and Computer Simulation, Vol. 8, No. 1, January 1998, pp 3--30.
Bug Fixes. This implementation implements the bug fixes made in Java 1.2's version of Random, which means it can be used with earlier versions of Java. See the JDK 1.2 java.util.Random documentation for further documentation on the random-number generation contracts made. Additionally, there's an undocumented bug in the JDK java.util.Random.nextBytes() method, which this code fixes.
Important Note. Just like java.util.Random, this generator accepts a long seed but doesn't use all of it. java.util.Random uses 48 bits. The Mersenne Twister instead uses 32 bits (int size). So it's best if your seed does not exceed the int range.
Sean Luke's web page
- added shuffling method (Alexei Drummond)
- added gamma RV method (Marc Suchard)
This is now package private - it should be accessed using the instance in Random

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualBasic.Math.MersenneTwisterFast.#ctor
member.summary: Constructor using the time of day as default seed.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualBasic.Math.MersenneTwisterFast.#ctor(System.Int64)
member.summary: Constructor using a given seed. Though you pass this seed in as a long, it's best to make sure it's actually an integer.
member.param: generator starting number, often the time of day.

member.name: P:Microsoft.VisualBasic.Math.MersenneTwisterFast.Seed
member.summary: Initalize the pseudo random number generator. The Mersenne Twister only uses an integer for its seed; It's best that you don't pass in a long that's bigger than an int.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualBasic.Math.MersenneTwisterFast.nextInt(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns an integer drawn uniformly from 0 to n-1. Suffice it to say, n must be > 0, or an IllegalArgumentException is raised.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualBasic.Math.MersenneTwisterFast.permute(System.Int32[])
member.summary: Returns a uniform random permutation of int objects in array

member.summary: Shuffles an array.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualBasic.Math.MersenneTwisterFast.shuffle(System.Int32[],System.Int32)
member.summary: Shuffles an array. Shuffles numberOfShuffles times

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualBasic.Math.MersenneTwisterFast.shuffled(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns an array of shuffled indices of length l.
member.param: length of the array required.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualBasic.Math.MersenneTwisterFast.permuted(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns a uniform random permutation of ints 0,...,l-1
member.param: length of the array required.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualBasic.Math.MersenneTwisterFast.nextGamma(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: **************************************************************** * Gamma Distribution - Acceptance Rejection combined with * Acceptance Complement * * ****************************************************************** * FUNCTION: - gds samples a random number from the standard * gamma distribution with parameter a > 0. * Acceptance Rejection gs for a < 1 , * Acceptance Complement gd for a >= 1 . * REFERENCES: - J.H. Ahrens, U. Dieter (1974): Computer methods * for sampling from gamma, beta, Poisson and * binomial distributions, Computing 12, 223-246. * - J.H. Ahrens, U. Dieter (1982): Generating gamma * variates by a modified rejection technique, * Communications of the ACM 25, 47-54. * SUBPROGRAMS: - drand(seed) ... (0,1)-Uniform generator with * unsigned long integer *seed * - NORMAL(seed) ... Normal generator N(0,1). * * *****************************************************************

member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualBasic.Math.Randomizer
member.summary:
##### Random generator based on the random table.(请注意，这个模块之中的所有函数都是线程不安全的)
###### A Million Random Digits with 100,000 Normal Deviates
Not long after research began at RAND in 1946, the need arose for random numbers that could be used to solve problems of various kinds of experimental probability procedures. These applications, called Monte Carlo methods, required a large supply of random digits and normal deviates of high quality, and the tables presented here were produced to meet those requirements. This book was a product of RAND's pioneering work in computing, as well a testament to the patience and persistence of researchers in the early days of RAND. The tables of random numbers in this book have become a standard reference in engineering and econometrics textbooks and have been widely used in gaming and simulations that employ Monte Carlo trials. Still the largest published source of random digits and normal deviates, the work is routinely used by statisticians, physicists, polltakers, market analysts, lottery administrators, and quality control engineers. A 2001 article in the New York Times on the value of randomness featured the original edition of the book, published in 1955 by the Free Press. The rights have since reverted to RAND, and in this digital age, we thought it appropriate to reissue a new edition of the book in its original format, with a new foreword by Michael D. Rich, RAND's Executive Vice President.
> http://www.rand.org/pubs/monograph_reports/MR1418.html
